{"abstract": "Wal-Mart Stores agreed to pay $33.5 million in back wages plus interest to settle a federal overtime lawsuit.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2007/01/26/business/26walmart.html", "snippet": "Wal-Mart Stores agreed to pay $33.5 million in back wages plus interest to settle a federal overtime lawsuit.", "lead_paragraph": "The United States Labor Department announced yesterday that Wal-Mart Stores had agreed to pay $33.5 million in back wages plus interest to settle a federal lawsuit that accused the company of violating overtime laws involving 86,680 workers.", "print_section": "C", "print_page": "7", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Wal-Mart Settles U.S. Suit About Overtime", "kicker": null, "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "Wal-Mart Settles U.S. Suit About Overtime", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "organizations", "value": "Wal-Mart Stores Inc", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "LABOR", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Working Hours", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Labor Department", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Suits and Litigation", "rank": 5, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Wages and Salaries", "rank": 6, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2007-01-26T05:00:00+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Steven Greenhouse", "person": [{"firstname": "Steven", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Greenhouse", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/b5bda9c7-5cff-59fb-9b8c-294c855d1df4", "word_count": 645, "uri": "nyt://article/b5bda9c7-5cff-59fb-9b8c-294c855d1df4"}

{"abstract": "Wal-Mart Stores and the Bharti Group of India have agreed to set up wholesale stores and a supply chain in India, eight months after they signed an initial agreement. Their venture will open its first wholesale store by the end of 2008, according to Rajan Mittal, the joint managing director of Bharti Enterprises, who spoke at a news conference in New Delhi. Wal-Mart signed a tentative agreement to start a wholesaling business with the Bharti Group in November. The venture, a 50-50 partnership known as Bharti Wal-Mart Private, is planning to open 10 to 15 wholesale stores over the next seven years to sell to small retailers, hotels and restaurants. The proposed Bharti venture would supply the retail market with goods that come directly from producers like farmers, craftsmen and artisans, Mr. Mittal said.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2007/08/07/business/worldbusiness/07fobriefs-WALMARTWHOLE_BRF.html", "snippet": "Wal-Mart Stores and the Bharti Group of India have agreed to set up wholesale stores and a supply chain in India, eight months after they signed an initial agreement. {"abstract": "Retail sales in Britain unexpectedly rose in July by the most in five months as price cuts by stores lured shoppers. ", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2007/08/17/business/worldbusiness/17fobriefs-RETAILSALESP_BRF.html", "snippet": "Retail sales in Britain unexpectedly rose in July by the most in five months as price cuts by stores lured shoppers. ", "lead_paragraph": "Retail sales in Britain unexpectedly rose in July by the most in five months as price cuts by stores lured shoppers. Sales climbed 0.7 percent after gaining 0.4 percent in June, which was twice as much as previously reported, the Office for National Statistics said. Tesco, Britain\u2019s biggest retailer, and Asda, owned by Wal-Mart Stores, cut prices on thousands of products to attract customers during the wettest summer on record. The gain in retail sales was led by electronics and furniture, the statistics office said. Household goods stores reported a 13.4 percent annual increase in sales, the biggest since October 2001. Retail sales rose 4.4 percent from a year earlier. Analysts said the strong figures would encourage the central bank to raise interest rates.", "print_section": "C", "print_page": "7", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Britain: Retail Sales Post Gain", "kicker": "World Business Briefing", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "Britain: Retail Sales Post Gain", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "glocations", "value": "Great Britain", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "RETAIL STORES AND TRADE", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Sales", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2007-08-17T04:00:00+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "World Business", "byline": {"original": "By Bloomberg News", "person": [{"firstname": "Bloomberg", "middlename": null, "lastname": "News", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "Brief", "_id": "nyt://article/d38634d7-faaa-5077-ab3c-09512932be03", "word_count": 126, "uri": "nyt://article/d38634d7-faaa-5077-ab3c-09512932be03"}

{"abstract": "Question of the day: Reports say Apple is negotiating to get more studios to sell movie downloads through iTunes. One reason is that they want to sell DVDs with extra copies that can be moved onto iPods. Would you pay $3 extra for this?", "web_url": "https://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2007/12/03/would-you-pay-more-for-a-dvd-with-an-itunes-copy/", "snippet": "Question of the day: Reports say Apple is negotiating to get more studios to sell movie downloads through iTunes. One reason is that they want to sell DVDs with extra copies that can be moved onto iPods. Would you pay $3 extra for this?", "lead_paragraph": "Richard Greenfield, the Pali Research analyst, writes this morning that he hears that the long standoff between Apple and Hollywood over movie downloads may be heading for a resolution. As of right now, Disney, of which Steve Jobs is a director and large shareholder, sells movies through the iTunes Store, and the other major studios don\u2019t. The issue has been that the studios want to charge more money for downloads than Mr. Jobs thinks they are worth. The studios also worry about offending Wal-Mart and Target, which are by far their largest distributors. (The report is here, but requires registration to see.) ", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "DVD Movies With an iTunes Copy: Worth More?", "kicker": "Bits", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [], "pub_date": "2007-12-03T16:00:21+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Technology", "byline": {"original": "By Saul Hansell", "person": [{"firstname": "Saul", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Hansell", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/35dbbedb-6b68-57de-a394-acfc050f9c98", "word_count": 336, "uri": "nyt://article/35dbbedb-6b68-57de-a394-acfc050f9c98"}

{"abstract": "After a period of experimentation with sleeker fashion and upscale merchandise Wal-Mart, in 2007, returned with a vengeance to the strategy that built it into the world\u2019s largest retailer: low prices.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2008/01/11/business/11walmart.html", "snippet": "After a period of experimentation with sleeker fashion and upscale merchandise Wal-Mart, in 2007, returned with a vengeance to the strategy that built it into the world\u2019s largest retailer: low prices.", "lead_paragraph": "Twelve months ago, long before fears of a recession loomed, senior executives at Wal-Mart Stores hatched a plan to \u201cdisrupt the marketplace\u201d during the 2007 holiday season, said Eduardo Castro-Wright, the chief executive of the company\u2019s United States division. {"abstract": "The giant discount retailer said that, after it introduced a revised health plan last fall, the number of workers who signed up reached 50.2 percent of its 1.4 million employees.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2008/01/22/business/23cnd-walmart.html", "snippet": "The giant discount retailer said that, after it introduced a revised health plan last fall, the number of workers who signed up reached 50.2 percent of its 1.4 million employees.", "lead_paragraph": "Wal-Mart Stores, the nation\u2019s largest private employer, said on Tuesday that for the first time in its 45-year history more than half of its workers had enrolled in the company\u2019s health insurance plan, a potent milestone for a retailer long associated with unaffordable benefits.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Wal-Mart Says Most Workers Have Health Plan", "kicker": null, "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "organizations", "value": "Wal-Mart Stores Inc", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Health Insurance and Managed Care", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2008-01-22T05:00:00+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Michael Barbaro", "person": [{"firstname": "Michael", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Barbaro", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/fcee608f-bde6-50e8-924b-78f1dda3b1f1", "word_count": 474, "uri": "nyt://article/fcee608f-bde6-50e8-924b-78f1dda3b1f1"}

{"abstract": "Wal-Mart, the nation\u2019s largest private employer, said more than half of its U.S. workers had enrolled in the company\u2019s health insurance plan.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2008/01/23/business/23walmart.html", "snippet": "Wal-Mart, the nation\u2019s largest private employer, said more than half of its U.S. workers had enrolled in the company\u2019s health insurance plan.", "lead_paragraph": "Wal-Mart, the nation\u2019s largest private employer, said on Tuesday that for the first time in its 46-year history more than half its United States workers had enrolled in the company\u2019s health insurance plan, a milestone for a retailer long criticized as offering unaffordable benefits.", "print_section": "C", "print_page": "2", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Wal-Mart Says More Than Half Its Workers Have Its Health Insurance", "kicker": null, "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "Wal-Mart Crosses a Health Insurance Threshold", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "organizations", "value": "Wal-Mart Stores Inc", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "RETAIL STORES AND TRADE", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Health Insurance and Managed Care", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "LABOR", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2008-01-23T05:00:00+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Michael Barbaro", "person": [{"firstname": "Michael", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Barbaro", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/bd7d9230-62d4-51db-9934-6d27a88f9953", "word_count": 584, "uri": "nyt://article/bd7d9230-62d4-51db-9934-6d27a88f9953"}

{"abstract": "As part of a campaign to upgrade its image by changing the way it does business, Wal-Mart has pledged to cut the energy used by many of its products by 25 percent.  ", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2008/01/24/business/24walmart.html", "snippet": "As part of a campaign to upgrade its image by changing the way it does business, Wal-Mart has pledged to cut the energy used by many of its products by 25 percent. {"abstract": "Chapter one of Steven Greenhouse\u2019s \u201cThe Big Squeeze: Tough Times for the American Worker.\u201d", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2008/04/20/business/20workexcerpt.html", "snippet": "Chapter one of Steven Greenhouse\u2019s \u201cThe Big Squeeze: Tough Times for the American Worker.\u201d", "lead_paragraph": "In the last couple of decades, corporate profits and executive salaries have soared. But for many workers, the only thing that has increased is insecurity. In \u201cThe Big Squeeze: Tough Times for the American Worker,\u201d Steven Greenhouse, a labor and workplace reporter for The New York Times, examines the difficulties faced by workers at companies like FedEx and Wal-Mart, and points to Patagonia and Costco as models for corporate America. The book was published by Knopf on April 15. Chapter One is excerpted here.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Worked Over and Overworked", "kicker": "Chapter One", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "Worked Over and Overworked", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "persons", "value": "Greenhouse, Steven", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2008-04-20T04:00:00+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "SundayBusiness", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "", "person": [], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/1a10f297-31b3-53b5-b0e4-c10f5c3f6bdc", "word_count": 5198, "uri": "nyt://article/1a10f297-31b3-53b5-b0e4-c10f5c3f6bdc"}

{"abstract": "A former executive with Wal-Mart, Allan Leighton, became president of Canada\u2019s largest grocery retailer, the Loblaw Companies, on Monday. Once known for its innovation, Loblaw has stumbled recently as the company deals with Wal-Mart Canada\u2019s gradual move into the grocery business. Mr. Leighton, left, was the chief executive of Asda Stores, a British supermarket chain, when it was acquired by Wal-Mart in 1996. He was subsequently made president and chief executive of Wal-Mart Europe and later became nonexecutive chairman of the Royal Mail of Britain. The Weston family of Toronto, who control Loblaw as well as several businesses in Britain, brought Mr. Leighton to the Canadian chain as deputy chairman in 2006, a position he will retain. Mark Foote, the company\u2019s president and chief merchandising officer, has left Loblaw, the company said, as has Pietro Satriano, its executive vice president for food.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2008/04/22/business/worldbusiness/22fobriefs-GROCERYCHAIN_BRF.html", "snippet": "A former executive with Wal-Mart, Allan Leighton, became president of Canada\u2019s largest grocery retailer, the Loblaw Companies, on Monday. {"abstract": "The Loblaw Companies reported an increase in first-quarter profit and said it planned to accelerate price and cost cuts to compete with Wal-Mart Stores.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2008/05/01/business/worldbusiness/01fobriefs-GROCERSPROFI_BRF.html", "snippet": "The Loblaw Companies reported an increase in first-quarter profit and said it planned to accelerate price and cost cuts to compete with Wal-Mart Stores.", "lead_paragraph": "The Loblaw Companies, Canada\u2019s largest supermarket chain, reported an increase in first-quarter profit and said it planned to accelerate price and cost cuts to compete with Wal-Mart Stores. Net income climbed 15 percent, to 62 million Canadian dollars ($61.2 million), or 23 cents a share, from 54 million Canadian dollars, or 20 cents a share, a year earlier, when it recorded costs for cutting jobs. Sales rose 2.8 percent, to 6.53 billion Canadian dollars. The executive chairman, Galen G. Weston, said price cuts would continue this year as Loblaw tries to blunt Wal-Mart\u2019s expansion into fresh foods across Canada. {"abstract": "Eighty-six percent of adults said they had shopped at a supermarket in the last month down from 93 percent in 2005, and stores like Wal-Mart have benefited.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2008/05/26/business/26drill.html", "snippet": "Eighty-six percent of adults said they had shopped at a supermarket in the last month down from 93 percent in 2005, and stores like Wal-Mart have benefited.", "lead_paragraph": "The percentage of adult food shoppers who said they had shopped at a supermarket over the last month has fallen from to 86 percent from 93 percent since 2005, according to \u201cU.S. Grocery Shopper Trends,\u201d a survey of customers\u2019 behavior prepared yearly by the Food Marketing Institute, a trade group.", "print_section": "C", "print_page": "3", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Some Shoppers Head to Supercenters", "kicker": "Drilling Down", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "Some Shoppers Head to Supercenters", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "RETAIL STORES AND TRADE", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Surveys and Series", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Wal-Mart Stores Inc", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Supermarkets", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2008-05-26T04:00:00+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Alex Mindlin", "person": [{"firstname": "Alex", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Mindlin", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/75314619-d6a3-552b-b572-3c2df3afb001", "word_count": 185, "uri": "nyt://article/75314619-d6a3-552b-b572-3c2df3afb001"}

{"abstract": "Canada\u2019s highest court agreed to hear an appeal by former employees of Wal-Mart Stores who say the company closed a store in Quebec because of a union drive.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2008/08/08/business/worldbusiness/08fobriefs-APPEALOFAWAL_BRF.html", "snippet": "Canada\u2019s highest court agreed to hear an appeal by former employees of Wal-Mart Stores who say the company closed a store in Quebec because of a union drive.", "lead_paragraph": "Canada\u2019s highest court agreed to hear an appeal by former employees of Wal-Mart Stores who say the company closed a store in Quebec because of a union drive. In 2004, employees at Wal-Mart\u2019s store in Jonqui\u00e8re became the company\u2019s first North American personnel organized by the United Food and Commercial Workers. Wal-Mart argued that the store, about 290 miles north of Montreal, was unprofitable and that its 2005 closing was unrelated to the union. Quebec\u2019s provincial labor commission dismissed the workers\u2019 complaint that they were fired for their union activities, saying Wal-Mart had showed adequate cause for its decision to close the store.", "print_section": "C", "print_page": "7", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Canada: Appeal of a Wal-Mart Closing", "kicker": "World Business Briefing | Americas", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "CANADA: APPEAL OF A WAL-MART CLOSING", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "organizations", "value": "Wal-Mart Stores Inc", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "glocations", "value": "Canada", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Organized Labor", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2008-08-08T01:33:56+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "World Business", "byline": {"original": "By Bloomberg News", "person": [{"firstname": "Bloomberg", "middlename": null, "lastname": "News", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "Brief", "_id": "nyt://article/08549335-713b-5199-bf7a-9d4ee4134ab0", "word_count": 105, "uri": "nyt://article/08549335-713b-5199-bf7a-9d4ee4134ab0"}

{"abstract": "Wal-Mart de M\u00e9xico said sales at stores open at least a year fell 1.1 percent in March.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2009/04/08/business/global/08fobriefs-MARCHWALMEXS_BRF.html", "snippet": "Wal-Mart de M\u00e9xico said sales at stores open at least a year fell 1.1 percent in March.", "lead_paragraph": "Wal-Mart de M\u00e9xico said sales at stores open at least a year fell 1.1 percent in March. Same-store sales fell in part because March had one fewer Saturday than last year and Easter, which was in March in 2008, is in April this year, the company said in a statement. Total revenue last month rose 5.9 percent to 21 billion pesos ($1.56 billion), the company, based in Mexico City, said. The number of transactions fell 0.5 percent on a comparable-store basis, said the company, known as Walmex. The value of the average transaction dropped 0.6 percent. Wal-Mart Stores owns two-thirds of Walmex. ", "print_section": "B", "print_page": "2", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Mexico: March Walmex Sales Fall", "kicker": "World Business Briefing | The Americas", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "MEXICO: MARCH WALMEX SALES FALL", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Shopping and Retail", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Wal-Mart Stores Inc", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Sales", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "glocations", "value": "Mexico", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2009-04-08T02:17:05+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "Global Business", "byline": {"original": "By Bloomberg News", "person": [{"firstname": "Bloomberg", "middlename": null, "lastname": "News", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "Brief", "_id": "nyt://article/63e97216-1981-504f-9556-9ef3d24d08e8", "word_count": 103, "uri": "nyt://article/63e97216-1981-504f-9556-9ef3d24d08e8"}

One that made the grade is KIND Fruit + Nut Bars.", "lead_paragraph": "Daniel Lubetzky, a social entrepreneur who has started several food ventures, always hoped to sell his company\u2019s KIND Fruit + Nut Bars in Starbucks Coffee stores \u0097 a chain whose values and consumers he felt meshed with his own. {"abstract": "Shareholders of CPI, which runs portrait studios in Wal-Mart stores, have backed all six of the company\u2019s directors, impeding an effort by the hedge fund Ramius to replace two members of the board.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2009/07/08/ramius-loses-second-proxy-battle-this-year/", "snippet": "Shareholders of CPI, which runs portrait studios in Wal-Mart stores, have backed all six of the company\u2019s directors, impeding an effort by the hedge fund Ramius to replace two members of the board.", "lead_paragraph": "Shareholders of CPI Corporation, which runs portrait studios in Wal-Mart stores and other locations, have backed all six of the company\u2019s chosen directors, dealing a blow to an effort by the hedge fund Ramius to replace two members of the board, according to preliminary results released Wednesday. {"abstract": "The Target Corporation plans to run its own Web site starting in 2011, ending a 10-year deal under with Amazon.com.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2009/08/08/business/08bizbriefs-target.html", "snippet": "The Target Corporation plans to run its own Web site starting in 2011, ending a 10-year deal under with Amazon.com.", "lead_paragraph": "The Target Corporation plans to run its own Web site starting in 2011, ending a 10-year deal under which Amazon.com fills the site\u2019s orders and provides customer support. Target, the second-largest discount retailer in the United States, after Wal-Mart, will take over building and managing Target.com before the 2011 holiday season, the company said in a statement on Friday. Amazon, the world\u2019s largest online retailer, agreed in 2001 to provide customer care, technology and order fulfillment for Target.com to help the discount retailer lower costs and improve customer service. \u201cWe\u2019ve had a very positive, productive relationship with Amazon,\u201d Kelly Basgen, a Target spokeswoman, said. However, she added, \u201cWe just thought it was in our best interest to grow and manage our own platform.\u201d Target said it would work with Amazon until the contract expired. ", "print_section": "B", "print_page": "2", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Target to End Deal With Amazon to Run Its Web Site", "kicker": "Business Briefing | Company News", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "Target to End Deal With Amazon to Run Its Web Site", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Shopping and Retail", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "AMAZON.COM INC", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Target Corp", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Computers and the Internet", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2009-08-08T01:25:44+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Bloomberg News", "person": [{"firstname": "Bloomberg", "middlename": null, "lastname": "News", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "Brief", "_id": "nyt://article/5943e6bf-a397-5c69-b522-3c672f5e39f4", "word_count": 137, "uri": "nyt://article/5943e6bf-a397-5c69-b522-3c672f5e39f4"}

{"abstract": "Prepaid debit cards are among the consumer banking industry\u2019s fastest-growing products, but often their convenience comes with hidden fees.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2009/10/06/your-money/06prepay.html", "snippet": "Prepaid debit cards are among the consumer banking industry\u2019s fastest-growing products, but often their convenience comes with hidden fees.", "lead_paragraph": "Buying a prepaid debit card these days is just about as easy as picking up a bottle of shampoo or a candy bar. Walk into a Wal-Mart or almost any major drugstore, and rows of plastic worth $25, $100 and even $500 beckon from kiosks alongside prepaid phone cards and gift cards for retailers. {"abstract": "Wal-Mart Stores reached an agreement with Live Nation Entertainment to sell tickets to concerts and other events at about 500 stores.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2010/02/13/business/13bizbriefs-WALMARTAGREE_BRF.html", "snippet": "Wal-Mart Stores reached an agreement with Live Nation Entertainment to sell tickets to concerts and other events at about 500 stores.", "lead_paragraph": "Wal-Mart Stores reached an agreement with Live Nation Entertainment to sell tickets to concerts and other events at about 500 stores. The service will be introduced in the next few months in cities including Chicago and Los Angeles, according to Irving Azoff, executive chairman of Live Nation. The new accord will let Wal-Mart shoppers buy tickets for concerts, sports and other events at cash registers in the retailer\u2019s entertainment department, Mr. Azoff said. Live Nation also sells tickets at Blockbuster stores. ", "print_section": "B", "print_page": "2", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Wal-Mart Agrees to Sell Live Nation Tickets", "kicker": "Business Briefing | Media", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "Wal-Mart Agrees To Sell Live Nation Tickets", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Shopping and Retail", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Live Nation Inc", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Wal-Mart Stores Inc", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2010-02-13T04:05:04+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Bloomberg News", "person": [{"firstname": "Bloomberg", "middlename": null, "lastname": "News", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "Brief", "_id": "nyt://article/dab98484-03c3-5f32-9668-ffafa40641e2", "word_count": 82, "uri": "nyt://article/dab98484-03c3-5f32-9668-ffafa40641e2"}

{"abstract": "Magnum, the Trojan subbrand of large condoms, is undertaking its first advertising campaign, called the Magnum Live Large Project, which features the rapper Ludacris.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2010/04/28/business/media/28adco.html", "snippet": "Magnum, the Trojan subbrand of large condoms, is undertaking its first advertising campaign, called the Magnum Live Large Project, which features the rapper Ludacris.", "lead_paragraph": " MAGNUM, the Trojan subbrand of large condoms, has climbed steadily from a 4.6 percent share of the condom market in 2001 to an 18.8 percent share today, according to the SymphonyIRI Group, a research firm whose data does not include Wal-Mart. {"abstract": "Kleenex packages made to look like slices of watermelon, orange or lime are meant to keep the product \u201crelevant\u201d when it is not cold and flu season.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2010/07/09/business/media/09adco.html", "snippet": "Kleenex packages made to look like slices of watermelon, orange or lime are meant to keep the product \u201crelevant\u201d when it is not cold and flu season.", "lead_paragraph": "SALES of facial tissue during the cold and flu season are, appropriately enough, feverish, but not so during the summer. In the four weeks that ended July 12, 2009, for example, revenue for the products totaled $57.8 million, compared with $92.4 million in the four weeks ending Jan. 24, 2010, a difference of nearly 60 percent, according to SymphonyIRI Group, a market research company whose data does not include Wal-Mart sales.", "print_section": "B", "print_page": "4", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [{"rank": 0, "subtype": "thumbnail", "caption": null, "credit": null, "type": "image", "url": "images/2010/07/09/business/09Adco1/09Adco1-thumbStandard.jpg", "height": 75, "width": 75, "subType": "thumbnail", "crop_name": "thumbStandard", "legacy": {"thumbnail": "images/2010/07/09/business/09Adco1/09Adco1-thumbStandard.jpg", "thumbnailwidth": 75, "thumbnailheight": 75}}], "headline": {"main": "A Sharp Focus on Design When the Package Is Part of the Product", "kicker": "Advertising", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "A Sharp Focus on Design When the Package Is Part of the Product", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Consumer Behavior", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Containers and Packaging", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "ADVERTISING AND MARKETING", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Kimberly-Clark Corporation", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2010-07-08T22:06:15+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "Media", "byline": {"original": "By Andrew Adam Newman", "person": [{"firstname": "Andrew", "middlename": "Adam", "lastname": "Newman", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/ce2f2b58-cb34-505f-83ba-5963fd83d347", "word_count": 920, "uri": "nyt://article/ce2f2b58-cb34-505f-83ba-5963fd83d347"}

{"abstract": "Economic reports this week will include retail sales for October and corporate earnings from Wal-Mart Stores, Dell and Target.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2010/11/15/business/15ahead.html", "snippet": "Economic reports this week will include retail sales for October and corporate earnings from Wal-Mart Stores, Dell and Target.", "lead_paragraph": "ECONOMIC REPORTS Data this week will include retail sales for October and business inventories for September (Monday); the Producer Price Index for October and industrial production and capacity utilization for October (Tuesday); the Consumer Price Index for October and housing starts for October (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims, the Philadelphia Fed manufacturing index, and leading economic indicators for October (Thursday).", "print_section": "B", "print_page": "3", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Looking Ahead to Economic Reports This Week", "kicker": null, "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "LOOKING AHEAD", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "United States Economy", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Economic Conditions and Trends", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2010-11-15T03:21:03+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "", "person": [], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "Schedule", "_id": "nyt://article/ebcf7726-4047-5363-a8bc-1346ef588d2d", "word_count": 299, "uri": "nyt://article/ebcf7726-4047-5363-a8bc-1346ef588d2d"}

{"abstract": "Ultimately, TerraCycle\u2019s goals are to make a lot of money, establish a global movement of waste collection, and change the way the world thinks about waste.", "web_url": "https://boss.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/04/06/introducing-green-money-turning-waste-into-profit/", "snippet": "Ultimately, TerraCycle\u2019s goals are to make a lot of money, establish a global movement of waste collection, and change the way the world thinks about waste.", "lead_paragraph": "My company, TerraCycle, has a very unusual business model. We turn the world\u2019s waste into new products. We collect non-recyclable waste, some straight from manufacturers and some from schools, charities and other community groups, and we partner with other manufacturers to recycle or \u201cupcycle\u201d that material into new products \u2014 like plastic lumber from juice pouches and shower curtains from sewn-together granola wrappers. My channel on this blog will be a diary of our experiences and decisions, our lessons learned and opportunities missed.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Introducing Sustainable Profits: Turning Waste Into Profit", "kicker": "You're the Boss", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Recycling of Waste Materials", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Shopping and Retail", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Small Business", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Wal-Mart Stores Inc", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}, {"name": "glocations", "value": "Trenton (NJ)", "rank": 5, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2011-04-06T11:00:17+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "Entrepreneurship", "byline": {"original": "By Tom Szaky", "person": [{"firstname": "Tom", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Szaky", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "", "_id": "nyt://article/b60df356-7069-503f-9368-bd5724fa06fb", "word_count": 825, "uri": "nyt://article/b60df356-7069-503f-9368-bd5724fa06fb"}

{"abstract": "We\u2019re looking for ways to get more people involved in our recycling programs.", "web_url": "https://boss.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/06/19/how-do-you-engage-your-customers/", "snippet": "We\u2019re looking for ways to get more people involved in our recycling programs.", "lead_paragraph": "At TerraCycle, consumers can interact with our business in two crucial ways. First, they can send us garbage (postage paid), and for each piece of waste they collect, we typically give 2 cents to the charity or school of their choice. Today, more than 21 million people in the United States are actively involved in our collection programs, and there\u2019s another 2 million participating outside of the United States. The second way to interact with TerraCycle is for consumers to buy the products that are made from the waste we\u2019ve collected. These products are typically available at major big-box stores, including Wal-Mart and Target.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "How Do You Engage Your Customers?", "kicker": "You're the Boss", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [], "pub_date": "2011-06-19T16:00:04+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "Entrepreneurship", "byline": {"original": "By Tom Szaky", "person": [{"firstname": "Tom", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Szaky", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/a4af9b70-d6b6-5f0d-8102-08880d95bdc3", "word_count": 752, "uri": "nyt://article/a4af9b70-d6b6-5f0d-8102-08880d95bdc3"}

{"abstract": "So far, TerraCycle has made three attempts at opening retail stores, and has failed three times.", "web_url": "https://boss.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/08/04/the-pipe-dream-of-opening-our-own-retail-stores/", "snippet": "So far, TerraCycle has made three attempts at opening retail stores, and has failed three times.", "lead_paragraph": "Since the inception of TerraCycle, I have dreamed of having our own chain of retail stores. Instead, we have always relied on stores like Wal-Mart and Whole Foods to sell our products. In the last decade, even as we shifted from selling home-and-garden products to selling a wide range of consumer products, and even as we shifted from manufacturing all our products to licensing them to assorted manufacturers, we\u2019ve continued to sell most of our stuff through big-box retailers.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "The (Pipe) Dream of Opening Our Own Retail Stores", "kicker": "You're the Boss", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Consumer Behavior", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Shopping and Retail", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Small Business", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "TerraCycle", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}, {"name": "glocations", "value": "Princeton (NJ)", "rank": 5, "major": "N"}, {"name": "glocations", "value": "Red Hook (NYC)", "rank": 6, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2011-08-04T17:00:48+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "Entrepreneurship", "byline": {"original": "By Tom Szaky", "person": [{"firstname": "Tom", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Szaky", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/61f51b58-1f4e-5688-a6ed-b18071064a77", "word_count": 213, "uri": "nyt://article/61f51b58-1f4e-5688-a6ed-b18071064a77"}

{"abstract": "The discount giant tried to take on iTunes with lower prices, but the plan fizzled.", "web_url": "https://mediadecoder.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/08/09/after-7-years-wal-mart-closes-its-mp3-store/", "snippet": "The discount giant tried to take on iTunes with lower prices, but the plan fizzled.", "lead_paragraph": "3:41 p.m. | Updated After more than seven years of selling digital music, Wal-Mart Stores will shut its MP3 store at the end of August, the company says.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "After 7 Years, Wal-Mart Closes Its MP3 Store", "kicker": "Media Decoder", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Audio Recordings and Downloads", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Music", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "iTunes", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Wal-Mart Stores Inc", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2011-08-09T19:25:20+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "Media", "byline": {"original": "By Ben Sisario", "person": [{"firstname": "Ben", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Sisario", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/1c806829-073f-5e95-a046-1e24f55e108a", "word_count": 241, "uri": "nyt://article/1c806829-073f-5e95-a046-1e24f55e108a"}

{"abstract": "Data will include the Producer Price Index, home sales and leading economic indicators, and companies including Wal-Mart, Dell and Gap will report earnings.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2011/08/15/business/economic-reports-for-the-week-of-aug-15.html", "snippet": "Data will include the Producer Price Index, home sales and leading economic indicators, and companies including Wal-Mart, Dell and Gap will report earnings.", "lead_paragraph": "ECONOMIC REPORTS Data this week will include housing starts, import prices and industrial production and capacity utilization for July (Tuesday); the Producer Price Index for July (Wednesday); and weekly jobless claims, the consumer price index, existing home sales and leading economic indicators for July, and the Philadelphia Fed manufacturing index for August (Thursday).", "print_section": "B", "print_page": "2", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Looking Ahead to Economic Reports This Week", "kicker": null, "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "Looking Ahead", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Economic Conditions and Trends", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2011-08-15T01:10:42+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "", "person": [], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "List", "_id": "nyt://article/bef986ab-d043-5c28-ae57-2be5727f2e2f", "word_count": 153, "uri": "nyt://article/bef986ab-d043-5c28-ae57-2be5727f2e2f"}

{"abstract": "Analysts said that chains were keeping inventories lean, using marketing dollars strategically and quickly marking down slow-moving items.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2011/08/17/business/wal-mart-and-home-depot-post-higher-profits.html", "snippet": "Analysts said that chains were keeping inventories lean, using marketing dollars strategically and quickly marking down slow-moving items.", "lead_paragraph": "Even as worries grow about another economic downturn, major retail companies continue to report strong earnings, thanks to tough lessons from the recession.", "print_section": "B", "print_page": "1", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [{"rank": 0, "subtype": "jumbo", "caption": null, "credit": null, "type": "image", "url": "images/2011/08/17/business/SHOP-1/SHOP-1-jumbo.jpg", "height": 700, "width": 1024, "subType": "jumbo", "crop_name": "jumbo", "legacy": {}}], "headline": {"main": "Retailers Glean Profit in Slow Sales", "kicker": null, "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "Retailers Glean Profit In Slow Sales", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "organizations", "value": "Home Depot Inc", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Wal-Mart Stores Inc", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Company Reports", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2011-08-16T12:51:56+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Stephanie Clifford", "person": [{"firstname": "Stephanie", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Clifford", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/cbe3c6b7-0338-52d1-941a-0ec7feb984fe", "word_count": 1011, "uri": "nyt://article/cbe3c6b7-0338-52d1-941a-0ec7feb984fe"}

{"abstract": "Jamestown Properties expects to spend $180 million to convert a 2.1-million-square-foot building into a mixed-use cluster of restaurants, apartments and office space.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2011/08/17/realestate/commercial/in-atlanta-big-plans-for-a-big-former-sears-center.html", "snippet": "Jamestown Properties expects to spend $180 million to convert a 2.1-million-square-foot building into a mixed-use cluster of restaurants, apartments and office space.", "lead_paragraph": "ATLANTA \u2014 As large as 20 Wal-Mart stores, the cavernous former Sears building now known as City Hall East towers above a motley assortment of restaurants, underground dance halls and a strip club a few miles northeast of downtown. {"abstract": "In a new book, Marc Levinson tells of A.& P.\u2019s swift expansion in the early 20th century, and the powerful backlash it engendered. The tale offers parallels to retail battles of today.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2011/09/04/business/in-aps-story-parallels-to-retail-battles-of-today.html", "snippet": "In a new book, Marc Levinson tells of A.& P.\u2019s swift expansion in the early 20th century, and the powerful backlash it engendered. The tale offers parallels to retail battles of today.", "lead_paragraph": "THIS is the story of a retailer that because of its sheer size could command volume discounts from its suppliers \u2014 and pass along the savings to customers. {"abstract": "Following some rivals, Wal-Mart will set aside products for delayed purchase, a sign of the financial pressures on shoppers.", "web_url": {"abstract": "The Walt Disney Company said that it would reorganize its approach to mass-market retailers and named a movie distribution executive to lead the effort.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2011/09/10/business/disney-reorganizes-its-retail-sales-system.html", "snippet": "The Walt Disney Company said that it would reorganize its approach to mass-market retailers and named a movie distribution executive to lead the effort.", "lead_paragraph": "The Walt Disney Company said that it would reorganize its approach to mass-market retailers and named a movie distribution executive to lead the effort. The executive, Robert Chapek, formerly president of distribution for Walt Disney Studios, will take over as president of Disney Consumer Products, succeeding Andrew P. Mooney, who resigned as chairman of that division on Tuesday. Mr. Chapek\u2019s first assignment will involve working with Disney\u2019s various units to create a more consolidated way of interacting with retailers like Wal-Mart. Disney currently handles merchandising in a decentralized fashion. The company\u2019s movie studio controls DVD sales. Disney Consumer Products manages apparel, toys and publishing. Another group oversees packaged video games. That means three different Disney teams typically interface with Wal-Mart and other big-box retailers. Disney\u2019s goal is to increase efficiency by having one point of contact. ", "print_section": "B", "print_page": "2", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Disney Reorganizes Its Retail Sales System", "kicker": "Business Briefing | MEDIA", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "Disney Reorganizes Its Retail Sales System", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Shopping and Retail", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Walt Disney Company", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2011-09-10T02:58:06+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Brooks Barnes", "person": [{"firstname": "Brooks", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Barnes", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "Brief", "_id": "nyt://article/61129d6e-1223-52a5-98ac-2f5791e511a6", "word_count": 137, "uri": "nyt://article/61129d6e-1223-52a5-98ac-2f5791e511a6"}

{"abstract": "Wal-Mart will cut prices to lure shoppers to the store before the traditional early opening on the Friday after the holiday.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2011/11/10/business/wal-mart-to-start-sales-at-10-pm-on-thanksgiving.html", "snippet": "Wal-Mart will cut prices to lure shoppers to the store before the traditional early opening on the Friday after the holiday.", "lead_paragraph": "With major retailers, including Kohl\u2019s, Macy\u2019s, Target and Best Buy, saying they will open at midnight on Thanksgiving this year to offer holiday deals, Wal-Mart is trying to do them one better. {"abstract": "Shoppers armed with tablets can use an app to get a sense of how different clothes might mix and match.", "web_url": "https://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/11/21/81121/", "snippet": "Shoppers armed with tablets can use an app to get a sense of how different clothes might mix and match.", "lead_paragraph": "Many retailers, as varied as Saks Fifth Avenue and Wal-Mart, are putting out new iPad apps in time for the holiday season, reports Claire Cain Miller of The New York Times. She says these apps do away with scrolling through pages of items online and make shopping more entertaining. About 60 percent of tablet owners use them to shop and many, especially young people, say they prefer shopping on tablets to smartphones and even computers. {"abstract": "Kroger, Safeway and Walgreen joined retailers removing Enfamil Premium Newborn formula from stores as regulators tested whether the product caused the death of a newborn.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2011/12/24/business/more-retailers-pull-baby-formula-from-shelves.html", "snippet": "Kroger, Safeway and Walgreen joined retailers removing Enfamil Premium Newborn formula from stores as regulators tested whether the product caused the death of a newborn.", "lead_paragraph": "Kroger, Safeway and Walgreen joined retailers removing Enfamil Premium Newborn formula from stores as regulators tested whether the product caused the death of a newborn. Mead Johnson\u2019s stock fell 5.1 percent to $65.29, after plunging 10 percent on Thursday when Walmart pulled the formula. Supervalu also has withdrawn the formula, a spokesman said. Officials screening samples of the formula and water used to prepare it said results might not come until next week. The newborn tested positive for Cronobacter sakazakii, an environmental bacterium that can be fatal. Another child infected with the bacterium in Missouri had also been given formula, though officials said on Friday that the baby, who survived, ingested other types of products as well. The brand of formula given to the second baby was not disclosed. {"abstract": "Advertisers distributed more than 272 billion coupons in free-standing inserts in 2011, according to a report from Kantar Media, a decline of 6.5 percent from 2010.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2012/01/17/business/media/accounts-and-people-of-note-in-the-ad-industry.html", "snippet": "Advertisers distributed more than 272 billion coupons in free-standing inserts in 2011, according to a report from Kantar Media, a decline of 6.5 percent from 2010.", "lead_paragraph": "Advertisers distributed more than 272 billion coupons in free-standing inserts in 2011, according to a report from Kantar Media, part of WPP, a decline of 6.5 percent from 2010. The drop came after two years of increases, of 8 percent in 2009 and 7.2 percent in 2010. The amount of promotion pages from retailers that appeared in the inserts, which are typically carried in Sunday newspapers, rose 30.7 percent last year compared with 2010, the report said; the retailers included Walmart, Dollar General, Target and Walgreens.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Accounts and People of Note in the Ad Industry", "kicker": "Webdenda", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "Webdenda", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "ADVERTISING AND MARKETING", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Public Relations and Publicity", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Hiring and Promotion", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2012-01-17T17:32:26+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "Media", "byline": {"original": "By The New York Times", "person": [], "organization": "The New York Times"}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/f23652fa-7824-5dbd-a77c-a429a6fc0631", "word_count": 1644, "uri": "nyt://article/f23652fa-7824-5dbd-a77c-a429a6fc0631"}

[{"abstract": "The administration of Mexican President Felipe Calder\u00f3n decided Wednesday to look into bribery payments after pressure from lawmakers and good government groups.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2012/04/26/business/global/wal-marts-permits-to-be-reviewed-by-mexico.html", "snippet": "The administration of Mexican President Felipe Calder\u00f3n decided Wednesday to look into bribery payments after pressure from lawmakers and good government groups.", "lead_paragraph": "MEXICO CITY \u2014 Two days after declaring it would not investigate bribery allegations tied to Wal-Mart\u2019s rapid expansion in Mexico, the Mexican government said Wednesday that it would review permits related to the approval of stores and seek information from American authorities.", "print_section": "B", "print_page": "6", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "In Shift, Mexico to Review Wal-Mart Permits", "kicker": null, "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "In Shift, Mexico to Review Wal-Mart Permits", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Bribery and Kickbacks", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Wal-Mart Stores Inc", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "glocations", "value": "Mexico", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "persons", "value": "Calderon, Felipe", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2012-04-26T01:00:22+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "Global Business", "byline": {"original": "By Randal C. {"abstract": "Unfortunately for shareholders, a recent complaint filed by a pension fund is unlikely to result in any significant changes at Wal-Mart Stores.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2012/05/07/a-tough-road-for-wal-mart-shareholders/", "snippet": "Unfortunately for shareholders, a recent complaint filed by a pension fund is unlikely to result in any significant changes at Wal-Mart Stores.", "lead_paragraph": "Wal-Mart shareholders are understandably upset with the company. The retailer\u2019s shares have taken a pounding after The New York Times reported on a bribery scandal at the company\u2019s Mexican subsidiary that some executives are said to have known about but chose to ignore. {"abstract": "Also, the show \u201cDirty Jobs\u201d has inspired a line of cleaning products that will be available online and in stores including Walmart.", "web_url": "https://mediadecoder.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/05/30/the-breakfast-meeting-court-rules-against-assange-and-hatfields-mccoys-pulls-in-viewers/", "snippet": "Also, the show \u201cDirty Jobs\u201d has inspired a line of cleaning products that will be available online and in stores including Walmart.", "lead_paragraph": "Britain\u2019s highest court has ruled that Julian Assange, the activist and founder of WikiLeaks, can be lawfully extradited to Sweden to face allegations over sexual abuse, John F. Burns and Ravi Somaiya write. {"abstract": "Data will include retail sales and leading economic indicators for July, and companies reporting results will include Groupon, Home Depot and Wal-Mart Stores.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2012/08/13/business/economic-reports-for-the-week-of-aug-13.html", "snippet": "Data will include retail sales and leading economic indicators for July, and companies reporting results will include Groupon, Home Depot and Wal-Mart Stores.", "lead_paragraph": "ECONOMIC REPORTS The data will include retail sales for July, the producer price index for July and business inventories for June (Tuesday); the Consumer Price Index for July and industrial production for July (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims, housing starts for July, and the Philadelphia Fed index for August\u00a0(Thursday); and the Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index for August and leading economic indicators for July (Friday).", "print_section": "B", "print_page": "2", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Economic Reports for the Week Ahead", "kicker": null, "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "Looking Ahead", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Economic Conditions and Trends", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Shopping and Retail", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Company Reports", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2012-08-12T21:38:09+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "", "person": [], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "Schedule", "_id": "nyt://article/c9679563-4622-55cd-9251-b2b32f9a059b", "word_count": 265, "uri": "nyt://article/c9679563-4622-55cd-9251-b2b32f9a059b"}

{"abstract": "A group of big retailers, including 7-Eleven, Best Buy, CVS and Wal-Mart, are forming a company that will offer a way for customers to buy things with their smartphones.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2012/08/16/technology/major-retailers-plan-mobile-payments-effort.html", "snippet": "A group of big retailers, including 7-Eleven, Best Buy, CVS and Wal-Mart, are forming a company that will offer a way for customers to buy things with their smartphones.", "lead_paragraph": "Cash, credit or debit? You may one day have far more choices to make at the checkout counter. "web_url": "https://mediadecoder.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/09/21/the-breakfast-meeting-universal-emi-deal-passes-in-europe-and-relief-at-news-corp/", "snippet": "Universal Music Group won Europe\u2019s approval for its $1.9 billion acquisition of EMI Music, Wal-Mart said it would stop carrying Amazon\u2019s Kindle, and PBS has a chance to win an Emmy for best drama.", "lead_paragraph": "Universal Music Group won Europe\u2019s approval on Friday for its $1.9 billion acquisition of the British-based EMI Music, Ben Sisario and James Kanter report. The approval came after Universal agreed to a series of concessions meant to foster competition even as the sale itself will reduce the number of major music labels to three from four. The concessions include the selling off about a third of EMI\u2019s assets including most of Parlophone, its flagship label in Europe, with acts like Coldplay, Pink Floyd and Kylie Minogue. A consolation for the newly enlarged Universal is that it will keep the Beatles.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "The Breakfast Meeting: Universal-EMI Deal Passes in Europe, and Relief at News Corp.", "kicker": "Media Decoder", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [], "pub_date": "2012-09-21T13:35:06+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "Media", "byline": {"original": "By Noam Cohen", "person": [{"firstname": "Noam", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Cohen", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/81261d8b-9cce-594d-9cd4-e96b8b3c8de6", "word_count": 514, "uri": "nyt://article/81261d8b-9cce-594d-9cd4-e96b8b3c8de6"}]

managers in an insider trading case are trying to discredit government witnesses. | About 804 million Facebook shares are becoming eligible ...", "lead_paragraph": "After heavy lobbying by the industry, the Securities and Exchange Commission failed earlier this year to adopt new rules designed to protect money market funds. {"abstract": "Jimmy Kimmel joined the 11:35 p.m. late-night sweepstakes with Jay Leno and David Letterman on Tuesday night, but it was Mr. Leno who won the night\u2019s ratings race; the man behind a Puerto Rican puppet that was the subject of a media firestorm in November has resigned; Lipton is launching a new advertising campaign for the company\u2019s black tea that urges consumers to \u201cDrink positive.\u201d", "web_url": "https://mediadecoder.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/01/10/the-breakfast-meeting-a-late-night-ratings-race-and-a-controversial-puppeteer-resigns/", "snippet": "Jimmy Kimmel joined the 11:35 p.m. late-night sweepstakes with Jay Leno and David Letterman on Tuesday night, but it was Mr. Leno who won the night\u2019s ratings race; the man behind a Puerto Rican puppet that was the subject of a media firestorm in N...", "lead_paragraph": "It was Jimmy Kimmel who joined the 11:35 p.m. late-night sweepstakes with Jay Leno and David Letterman on Tuesday, but it was Mr. Leno who won the night\u2019s ratings race. Mr. Leno on NBC pulled in 3.27 million viewers, edging Mr. Kimmel on ABC, who had 3.1 million. The total for Mr. Kimmel was his second highest. It also put him in second place, ahead of David Letterman on CBS, who had 2.88 million viewers. As Bill Carter reports, Mr. Leno was also the winner in the audience of most interest to late-night advertisers \u2014 viewers between the ages of 18 and 49. Mr. Leno had 1.084 million viewers in that group to 887,000 for Mr. Kimmel and 683,000 for Mr. Letterman.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "The Breakfast {"abstract": "The retailer\u2019s 10-year commitment, totaling $50 billion, comes as it is under pressure over its overseas sourcing following a deadly fire in November in Bangladesh.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2013/01/16/business/walmart-to-offer-more-us-made-goods.html", "snippet": "The retailer\u2019s 10-year commitment, totaling $50 billion, comes as it is under pressure over its overseas sourcing following a deadly fire in November in Bangladesh.", "lead_paragraph": "The manufacturer 1888 Mills produces most of its sheets and towels overseas, in part to keep costs low for retailers like Walmart. {"abstract": "The refrigerated dog food maker takes a patriotic turn in a new campaign to highlight its fresh ingredients.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2013/06/14/business/media/freshpet-dog-food-promotes-products-sourced-in-the-us.html", "snippet": "The refrigerated dog food maker takes a patriotic turn in a new campaign to highlight its fresh ingredients.", "lead_paragraph": "IN 2006, when Freshpet introduced dog food that required refrigeration, a novelty in the pet food aisle, retailers were skeptical that they should remodel to accommodate the free refrigerators the brand offered. But after widespread pet food recalls in 2007 linked to contaminated wheat gluten from China, consumers and retailers both warmed to the brand\u2019s promise of fresh ingredients without preservatives, and distribution today has grown to about 9,200 stores, including Walmart, Target, Whole Foods and Petco.", "print_section": "B", "print_page": "8", "source": "The New York Times", {"abstract": "Sponsorship spending for cause marketing is expected to total $1.78 billion this year, up almost 5 percent over last year.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2013/09/30/business/media/accounts-and-people-of-note-in-the-advertising-industry.html", "snippet": "Sponsorship spending for cause marketing is expected to total $1.78 billion this year, up almost 5 percent over last year.", "lead_paragraph": "Sponsorship spending for cause marketing is expected to total $1.78 billion this year, according to IEG, Chicago, up 4.8 percent from $1.7 billion last year. By comparison, spending last year rose only 1.2 percent from 2011. The most active companies sponsoring causes \u2013 as determined by the percentage of causes reporting the companies as sponsors \u2013 are Bank of America, 18 percent; Coca-Cola, 14 percent; and three tied at 13 percent: Wells Fargo, Johnson & Johnson and Wal-Mart Stores.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry", "kicker": "Webdenda", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "ADVERTISING AND MARKETING", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Hiring and Promotion", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Public Relations and Publicity", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Appointments and Executive Changes", "rank": 5, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2013-09-30T13:32:10+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "Media", "byline": {"original": "By The New York Times", "person": [], "organization": "The New York Times"}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/38906395-26b5-57d1-ad53-3b0dbb65ea9d", "word_count": 742, "uri": "nyt://article/38906395-26b5-57d1-ad53-3b0dbb65ea9d"}

{"abstract": "Target, a retailer with about 347,000 workers in the United States, reportedly has told employees they will start to get higher wages this spring.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2015/03/19/business/target-plans-to-raise-pay-to-at-least-9-an-hour.html", "snippet": "Target, a retailer with about 347,000 workers in the United States, reportedly has told employees they will start to get higher wages this spring.", "lead_paragraph": "Target said on Wednesday that it would increase the pay of its workers to at least $9 an hour, joining retailers like Walmart and TJX in raising its hourly wage in a more competitive job market and facing pressure from labor groups.", "print_section": "B", "print_page": "5", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Target Plans to Raise Pay to at Least $9 an Hour", "kicker": null, "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "Target Plans to Raise Pay to at Least $9 an Hour", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "organizations", "value": "Target Corporation", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Wages and Salaries", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Labor and Jobs", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Walmart Stores Inc", "rank": 5, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2015-03-19T00:16:16+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Hiroko Tabuchi", "person": [{"firstname": "Hiroko", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Tabuchi", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/344b0f49-790b-5368-86c6-3022bc577405", "word_count": 303, "uri": "nyt://article/344b0f49-790b-5368-86c6-3022bc577405"}

{"abstract": "Walmart, Home Depot and Target are among the retailers posting results this week; Japan will report its G.D.P. on Wednesday; and the big Wall Street banks will hold their annual meetings with shareholders.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2015/05/18/business/earnings-from-walmart-and-more-big-retailers-wall-streets-annual-meetings.html", "snippet": "Walmart, Home Depot and Target are among the retailers posting results this week; Japan will report its G.D.P. on Wednesday; and the big Wall Street banks will hold their annual meetings with shareholders.", "lead_paragraph": "A wave of retailers will report first-quarter earnings this week, including Home Depot, Walmart and TJX on Tuesday; Target, Lowe\u2019s and Staples on Wednesday; and Best Buy, Gap, Ross Stores and Dollar Tree on Thursday. Analysts are paying particular attention to how well these stores weathered the post-holiday lull and wintry weather early this year. They will also be looking for effects of rising labor costs as a tightening job market forces retailers \u2014 some of the country\u2019s largest employers \u2014 to start increasing wages for their lowest-paid workers. \u2014Hiroko Tabuchi", "print_section": "B", "print_page": "2", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [{"rank": 0, "subtype": "xlarge", "caption": null, "credit": null, "type": "image", "url": "images/2015/05/18/business/18AHEAD1/18AHEAD1-articleLarge.jpg", "height": 407, "width": 600, "subType": "xlarge", "crop_name": "articleLarge", "legacy": {"xlarge": "images/2015/05/18/business/18AHEAD1/18AHEAD1-articleLarge.jpg", "xlargewidth": 600, "xlargeheight": 407}}, {"rank": 0, "subtype": "jumbo", "caption": null, "credit": null, "type": "image", "url": "images/2015/05/18/business/18AHEAD1/18AHEAD1-jumbo.jpg", "height": 694, "width": 1024, "subType": "jumbo", "crop_name": "jumbo", "legacy": {}}, {"rank": 0, "subtype": "superJumbo", "caption": null, "credit": null, "type": "image", "url": "images/2015/05/18/business/18AHEAD1/18AHEAD1-superJumbo.jpg", "height": 1388, "width": 2048, "subType": "superJumbo", "crop_name": "superJumbo", "legacy": {}}, {"rank": 0, "subtype": "thumbnail", "caption": null, "credit": null, "type": "image", "url": "images/2015/05/18/business/18AHEAD1/18AHEAD1-thumbStandard.jpg", "height": 75, "width": 75, "subType": "thumbnail", "crop_name": "thumbStandard", "legacy": {"thumbnail": "images/2015/05/18/business/18AHEAD1/18AHEAD1-thumbStandard.jpg", "thumbnailwidth": 75, "thumbnailheight": 75}}, {"rank": 0, "subtype": "thumbLarge", "caption": null, "credit": null, "type": "image", "url": "images/2015/05/18/business/18AHEAD1/18AHEAD1-thumbLarge.jpg", "height": 150, "width": 150, "subType": "thumbLarge", "crop_name": "thumbLarge", "legacy": {}}], "headline": {"main": "Earnings From Walmart and More Big Retailers; [{"abstract": "Erasing student loans requires proof that paying the debt would cause \u201cundue hardship,\u201d and some judges think the rigid standard should be reconsidered.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/18/your-money/student-loans/judges-rebuke-limits-on-wiping-out-student-loan-debt.html", "snippet": "Erasing student loans requires proof that paying the debt would cause \u201cundue hardship,\u201d and some judges think the rigid standard should be reconsidered.", "lead_paragraph": "On a typical day in her last job, Janet Roth left home at 4 a.m. each day and drove 40 miles to a tax preparation office in Glendale, Ariz. [{"abstract": "This week, some of the nation's biggest retailers report earnings, the Federal Reserve will publish an account of its July meeting, and Greece must make a critical repayment.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/17/business/retailer-earnings-fed-minutes-and-greek-debt.html", "snippet": "This week, some of the nation's biggest retailers report earnings, the Federal Reserve will publish an account of its July meeting, and Greece must make a critical repayment.", "lead_paragraph": "Some of the nation\u2019s biggest retailers report earnings this week, including Walmart and Home Depot, which announce second-quarter results on Tuesday, and Target, whose announcement is on Wednesday. Walmart has invested heavily in its stores, as well as in its online business and work force, as part of a bid to overcome a prolonged decline in sales and market share. Still, analysts do not expect big results soon. On the other hand, Home Depot, the home improvement retailer, has been riding a recovery in the housing market to sales gains, and analysts expect it to book a solid quarter. Also reporting this week are TJX on Tuesday; Staples, Lowe\u2019s and American Eagle Outfitters on Wednesday; and Foot Locker on Friday. \u2014Hiroko Tabuchi", "print_section": "B", "print_page": "2", {"abstract": "It\u2019s tough to be seen as a successful billionaire businessman who is also an outsider trying to work for the little guy.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2016/08/09/business/dealbookemail/trumps-economic-agenda-and-the-team-behind-it.html", "snippet": "It\u2019s tough to be seen as a successful billionaire businessman who is also an outsider trying to work for the little guy.", "lead_paragraph": "Donald J. Trump has laid out his economic vision, and it included deep tax cuts for the wealthy, tearing up climate change agreements and abandoning trade deals. He insisted, \u201cWe can\u2019t fix a rigged system by relying on the people who rigged it in the first place,\u201d highlighting the fine line that he has to tread between between being anti-elite and yet absolutely elite.
